rules.title: Subordinate Clauses
rules.description: Subordinate clauses are introduced by conjunctions like 'weil', 'dass', 'wenn'. The verb goes to the end.
examples: Ich bleibe zu Hause, weil es regnet. (I'm staying home because it's raining.)
Er sagt, dass er müde ist. (He says that he is tired.)
Wenn du Zeit hast, rufe mich an. (If you have time, call me.)
rules.notes: If the subordinate clause comes first, the main clause verb comes immediately after.

rules.title: Genitive Case
rules.description: The genitive case shows possession or relationships between nouns.
examples: Das Auto des Mannes (The man's car)
Das Haus meiner Eltern (My parents' house)
Die Farbe des Himmels (The color of the sky)
rules.notes: Articles: der→des, die→der, das→des, die(pl)→der. Masculine/neuter nouns add -(e)s.

rules.title: Passive Voice
rules.description: The passive voice emphasizes the action rather than who performs it. Formed with werden + past participle.
examples: Das Auto wird repariert. (The car is being repaired.)
Der Brief wurde geschrieben. (The letter was written.)
Das Haus wird gebaut. (The house is being built.)
rules.notes: The agent can be introduced with 'von' + dative.

rules.title: Konjunktiv II (Subjunctive)
rules.description: Used for hypothetical situations, polite requests, and wishes.
examples: Ich würde gerne kommen. (I would like to come.)
Wenn ich Zeit hätte, würde ich helfen. (If I had time, I would help.)
Könntest du mir helfen? (Could you help me?)
rules.notes: Often formed with würde + infinitive, except for common verbs like haben, sein, können.

rules.title: Relative Clauses
rules.description: Relative clauses provide additional information about a noun. They use relative pronouns (der, die, das).
examples: Der Mann, der dort steht, ist mein Lehrer. (The man who is standing there is my teacher.)
Das Buch, das ich lese, ist spannend. (The book that I'm reading is exciting.)
Die Frau, mit der ich spreche, ist nett. (The woman with whom I'm speaking is nice.)
rules.notes: The verb goes to the end of the relative clause.

rules.title: Simple Past (Präteritum) - Regular Verbs
rules.description: The simple past is primarily used in written German. Regular verbs add -te to the stem.
examples: ich lernte (I learned)
du machtest (you did)
er/sie/es sagte (he/she/it said)
wir spielten (we played)
sie arbeiteten (they worked)
rules.notes: In spoken German, Perfekt is preferred. Präteritum is mainly used in formal writing and storytelling.

rules.title: Simple Past - Irregular Verbs
rules.description: Irregular verbs change their stem vowel in the simple past and must be memorized.
examples: gehen → ging (to go → went)
kommen → kam (to come → came)
sehen → sah (to see → saw)
nehmen → nahm (to take → took)
geben → gab (to give → gave)
rules.notes: Modal verbs and common verbs like haben, sein are often used in Präteritum even in speech.

rules.title: Infinitive with 'zu'
rules.description: Many verbs and expressions require 'zu' before an infinitive.
examples: Ich hoffe, dich bald zu sehen. (I hope to see you soon.)
Es ist wichtig, Deutsch zu lernen. (It is important to learn German.)
Ich habe keine Zeit, ins Kino zu gehen. (I have no time to go to the cinema.)
Sie versucht, pünktlich zu sein. (She tries to be punctual.)
rules.notes: With separable verbs, 'zu' goes between prefix and verb: anzufangen, aufzustehen.

rules.title: Genitive Prepositions
rules.description: Certain prepositions always require the genitive case.
examples: während des Tages (during the day)
wegen des Wetters (because of the weather)
trotz der Kälte (despite the cold)
außerhalb der Stadt (outside the city)
innerhalb einer Woche (within a week)
rules.notes: Common genitive prepositions: während, wegen, trotz, statt, außerhalb, innerhalb.

rules.title: Adverbs of Degree
rules.description: Adverbs that modify adjectives or other adverbs to show degree or intensity.
examples: sehr gut (very good)
ziemlich müde (quite tired)
etwas kalt (somewhat cold)
besonders schön (especially beautiful)
völlig verrückt (completely crazy)
kaum sichtbar (barely visible)
rules.notes: These adverbs come before the adjective/adverb they modify.

rules.title: Compound Nouns
rules.description: German frequently combines words to create new nouns. The gender is determined by the last word.
examples: das Haus + die Tür → die Haustür (front door)
der Apfel + der Saft → der Apfelsaft (apple juice)
die Arbeit + das Zimmer → das Arbeitszimmer (office/study)
die Hand + der Schuh → der Handschuh (glove)
rules.notes: Sometimes a connecting element (-s-, -n-, -en-) is added between words.

rules.title: Adjectival Nouns
rules.description: Adjectives can be used as nouns and are capitalized. They still take adjective endings.
examples: der/die Deutsche (the German person)
ein Deutscher (a German man)
eine Deutsche (a German woman)
etwas Schönes (something beautiful)
nichts Neues (nothing new)
alles Gute (all the best)
rules.notes: These follow adjective declension rules depending on the article or lack thereof.

rules.title: Indirect Questions
rules.description: Indirect questions are subordinate clauses introduced by question words or 'ob'. The verb goes to the end.
examples: Ich weiß nicht, wo er wohnt. (I don't know where he lives.)
Sie fragt, ob du kommst. (She asks if you are coming.)
Er möchte wissen, wann der Zug fährt. (He wants to know when the train leaves.)
Kannst du mir sagen, wie spät es ist? (Can you tell me what time it is?)
rules.notes: Use 'ob' for yes/no questions, question words (wer, was, wo, wann, etc.) for others.

rules.title: Word Order: Time-Manner-Place (TeKaMoLo)
rules.description: When multiple adverbial phrases occur, they follow the order: Time (Te), Cause (Ka), Manner (Mo), Place (Lo).
examples: Ich fahre morgen (Te) mit dem Auto (Mo) nach Berlin (Lo). (I'm driving to Berlin tomorrow by car.)
Sie geht heute (Te) wegen der Arbeit (Ka) schnell (Mo) nach Hause (Lo). (She's going home quickly today because of work.)
Wir treffen uns am Montag (Te) im Café (Lo). (We're meeting on Monday at the café.)
rules.notes: This is a guideline, not a strict rule. Context and emphasis can change the order.

rules.title: Comparative Structures (als/wie)
rules.description: 'Als' is used for inequality (more/less than), 'wie' for equality (as...as).
examples: Er ist größer als ich. (He is taller than I.)
Sie läuft schneller als ihr Bruder. (She runs faster than her brother.)
Das Buch ist so interessant wie der Film. (The book is as interesting as the film.)
Ich bin genauso müde wie du. (I am just as tired as you.)
rules.notes: Remember: 'als' for comparatives, 'wie' for equality.

rules.title: Double Infinitive Construction
rules.description: In perfect tense with modal verbs, use double infinitive instead of past participle.
examples: Ich habe nicht kommen können. (I wasn't able to come.)
Er hat das Auto reparieren müssen. (He had to repair the car.)
Sie hat Deutsch lernen wollen. (She wanted to learn German.)
Wir haben lange warten müssen. (We had to wait a long time.)
rules.notes: The modal verb appears as infinitive, not as past participle (gekonnt, gemusst, etc.).

rules.title: N-Declension (Weak Masculine Nouns)
rules.description: Certain masculine nouns add -(e)n in all cases except nominative singular.
examples: der Herr → des Herrn, dem Herrn, den Herrn
der Student → des Studenten, dem Studenten, den Studenten
Ich kenne den Studenten. (I know the student.)
Das Auto des Kollegen ist neu. (The colleague's car is new.)
rules.notes: Common n-declension nouns: der Mensch, der Junge, der Nachbar, der Kunde, der Name.

rules.title: Distinguishing als, wenn, wann
rules.description: Three words meaning 'when', each used in different contexts.
examples: als (when, one time in past): Als ich jung war, lebte ich in Berlin. (When I was young, I lived in Berlin.)
wenn (when, repeated/future): Wenn ich Zeit habe, lese ich gern. (When I have time, I like to read.)
wann (when, in questions): Wann kommst du? (When are you coming?)
rules.notes: 'Als' = one-time past event, 'wenn' = repeated/future actions, 'wann' = questions/indirect questions.

rules.title: Lassen + Infinitive
rules.description: 'Lassen' with an infinitive expresses causing/allowing something or having something done.
examples: Ich lasse mein Auto reparieren. (I'm having my car repaired.)
Sie lässt mich nicht gehen. (She doesn't let me go.)
Lass uns nach Hause gehen! (Let's go home!)
Er ließ den Brief übersetzen. (He had the letter translated.)
rules.notes: Can mean 'to let/allow', 'to have something done', or 'to leave something in a state'.

rules.title: Placeholder 'es'
rules.description: 'Es' can occupy first position in a sentence, disappearing when another element moves to first position.
examples: Es kommen viele Gäste. (Many guests are coming.)
Morgen kommen viele Gäste. (Tomorrow many guests are coming.)
Es gibt viele Probleme. (There are many problems.)
Es ist wichtig, pünktlich zu sein. (It is important to be punctual.)
rules.notes: Not to be confused with 'es' as a pronoun. This 'es' has no meaning and just fills first position.

rules.title: Plusquamperfekt (Past Perfect)
rules.description: The past perfect tense expresses an action that was completed before another past action. Formed with hatte/war + past participle.
examples: Ich hatte schon gegessen, als er ankam. (I had already eaten when he arrived.)
Sie war schon nach Hause gegangen, bevor es regnete. (She had already gone home before it rained.)
Nachdem er das Buch gelesen hatte, gab er es zurück. (After he had read the book, he gave it back.)
Er hatte die Prüfung bestanden, bevor er die gute Nachricht bekam. (He had passed the exam before he got the good news.)
rules.notes: Use 'hatte' with most verbs, 'war' with motion/change of state verbs (same as perfect tense). Common with temporal conjunctions: nachdem, bevor, als.
